Summary (high level)
- The three categories differ clearly by (1) where a pronounced positive “bell” appears (begin, none, or end) and (2) the sign and level of the long central plateau.
  - Category 0 (Begin): a distinct positive peak early in the series, followed by a long negative central plateau, small/no late peak.
  - Category 1 (Middle): no early or late bell; instead a long, high positive central plateau (almost constant ≈ +0.98).
  - Category 2 (End): no early bell, a deep negative central plateau, and a pronounced positive bell near the series end.
- These differences are large in amplitude and in time location, so the classes are easily separable by a few simple features (early-peak energy, central-plateau sign/level, late-peak energy).

Recommended segmentation
- Early: indices ~0–31 (first ~25% of the 128 points)
- Middle (central plateau): indices ~32–95 (the long flat region)
- Late: indices ~96–127 (final ~25%)

Detailed comparison by segment

1) Early segment (0–31)
- Category 0 (Begin)
  - Clear positive “bell” here. Peaks reach ~0.7–1.1 in the early-mid early segment (samples show maxima ≈ 1.0 around indices ~6–12).
  - Values rise from near zero up to the peak then fall toward the central plateau.
- Category 1 (Middle)
  - Only small fluctuations and low-amplitude noise in the early segment (values mostly near 0–0.05).
  - No pronounced positive bell.
- Category 2 (End)
  - Early segment shows low-amplitude noise / small fluctuations (similar scale to Category 1), no early bell.

Conclusion: the early positive peak is a distinctive marker of Category 0 only.

2) Middle / central plateau (32–95)
- Category 0 (Begin)
  - Long, stable negative plateau. Values are around -0.9 to -0.96 for many consecutive points (low variance over long duration).
- Category 1 (Middle)
  - Long, stable positive plateau. Values cluster tightly around ≈ +0.97–0.99 (very low variance).
- Category 2 (End)
  - Long, stable negative plateau but deeper than Category 0: values around −1.35 to −1.39 in many locations (slightly more negative than Cat.0).
  
Conclusion: central-plateau sign and level is a second major discriminant:
  - Cat.1 = positive plateau (~+1)
  - Cat.0 & Cat.2 = negative plateau, with Cat.2 generally deeper (more negative) than Cat.0.

3) Late segment (96–127)
- Category 0 (Begin)
  - After the negative plateau the series returns toward small positive fluctuations; late values are small (≈ 0–0.05). No large late bell.
- Category 1 (Middle)
  - Late segment again shows small-amplitude fluctuations/noise (≈ 0–0.05). No late bell.
- Category 2 (End)
  - Pronounced positive bell near the end: values rise to ~0.8–0.96 around indices roughly in this late window (a clear end-located peak followed by small decay).

Conclusion: the late positive peak is a distinctive marker of Category 2 only.

Other observations
- Variability: Category 1 samples are almost identical here (very low within-class variance), and its plateau is very flat and high. Category 0 and 2 show similar overall pattern (peak vs plateau vs recovery) but differ in which side the peak occurs and in plateau depth (Cat.2 more negative).
- Temporal localization: Bells are localized (narrow-ish) compared with the long central plateau. This makes detection robust by simple windowed features: energy in early window, mean of central window, energy in late window.
- Practical discriminants (simple features that will separate classes well):
  - Mean(center window) sign (+ vs −) — separates Category 1 from the others.
  - Peak energy or max in early window — identifies Category 0.
  - Peak energy or max in late window — identifies Category 2.
  - Magnitude of negative plateau distinguishes Cat.0 vs Cat.2 (Cat.2 is more negative).

If you want, I can:
- Compute numerical summaries (means, standard deviations, exact index ranges of peaks) for each sample and each segment.
- Provide a toy rule (e.g., threshold on early-max, center-mean, late-max) that classifies these samples.

The late segment returns to small positive/noise values and does not contain a large end-located bell. This pattern (early positive peak + negative central plateau + no late peak) matches Category 0 (Begin).

- Category 0 (Begin)

  - Middle (30–90): a long, strongly negative central plateau (around −0.9 to −0.96) dominates most of the middle segment.

- Amplitude/duration: bells are relatively large (≈0.7–1.0) and fairly localized; the central plateaus are long and steady.
- Edge/noise behavior: all classes show small-amplitude noise-like fluctuations outside the main bell/plateau regions; those are not discriminative.

- mean (or median) of the central segment (sign and magnitude)
- location (index) of the global peak and its amplitude
- duration (width) of the high-amplitude region (to distinguish a sustained plateau vs a sharp peak)
